awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Advancing Secondary Mathematics Teachers' Quantitative Reasoning
awd_abstract_narration:
Science, Technology, Engineering  and Mathematics [STEM] and STEM education researchers and policy documents have directed mathematics educators at all levels to increase emphasis on quantitative reasoning so that students are prepared for continued studies in mathematics and other STEM fields. Often, teachers are not sufficiently prepared to support their students' quantitative reasoning. The products generated by this project fill a need for concrete materials at the pre-service level that embody research-based knowledge in the area of quantitative reasoning. The accessible collection of research and educational products provides a model program for changing prospective mathematics teachers' quantitative reasoning that is adoptable at other institutions across the nation.  Additionally, the support of early CAREER scholars in mathematics education will add to the capacity of the country to address issues in mathematics education in the future. 

Advancing Reasoning addresses the lack of materials for teacher education by investigating pre-service secondary mathematics teachers' quantitative reasoning in the context of secondary mathematics concepts including function and algebra. The project extends prior research in quantitative reasoning to develop differentiated instructional experiences and curriculum that support prospective teachers' quantitative reasoning and produce shifts in their knowledge. Three interrelated research questions guide the project: (i) What aspects of quantitative reasoning provide support for prospective teachers' understanding of major secondary mathematics concepts such as function and algebra? (ii) How can instruction support prospective teachers' quantitative reasoning in the context of the teaching and learning of major secondary mathematics concepts such as function and algebra? (iii) How do the understandings prospective teachers hold upon entering a pre-service program support or inhibit their quantitative reasoning?  Advancing Reasoning addresses these questions by enacting an iterative, multi-phase study with 200 prospective teachers enrolled in a secondary mathematics education content course over 5 years. The main phase of the study implements a series of classroom design experiments to produce knowledge on central aspects of prospective teachers' quantitative reasoning and the instructional experiences that support such reasoning. By drawing this knowledge from a classroom setting, Advancing Reasoning contributes research-based and practice-driven deliverables that improve the teaching and learning of mathematics.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

inst.inst_name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past 20 years, researchers and policy documents, including the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics (CCSSM), have directed mathematics educators at all levels to increase emphasis on quantitative reasoning. Unfortunately, quantitative reasoning?reasoning that helps us model the complex world around us?has remained mostly absent from the teaching and learning of mathematics, particularly at the middle and secondary grades level. A byproduct of this absence is that students are not being prepared for continued studies in mathematics and other STEM fields. Complicating the matter, teachers are not being sufficiently prepared to support their students' quantitative reasoning.

This project, titled Advancing Reasoning, addressed the aforementioned situation by investigating pre- and in-service secondary mathematics teachers' (PSTs' and ISTs?) quantitative reasoning in the context of secondary mathematics concepts including function and algebra. The project also investigated middle school students? quantitative reasoning. In doing so, the project extended prior work in the area of quantitative reasoning in order to develop differentiated instructional experiences and curriculum that support PSTs', ISTs?, and middle school students? quantitative reasoning and produce transformational shifts in their knowledge. Three interrelated research questions guided the project: (i) What aspects of quantitative reasoning provide support for PSTs', ISTs?, and middle school students? understanding of major mathematics concepts such as function and algebra? (ii) How can instruction support these populations? quantitative reasoning in the context of the teaching and learning of major mathematics concepts such as function and algebra? (iii) How do the understandings these populations hold support or inhibit their quantitative reasoning?

 

Advancing Reasoning addressed these questions by enacting an iterative, multi-phase study with PSTs enrolled in a secondary mathematics education content course, ISTs instructing secondary mathematics students, and middle school students initial graphical learning experiences. The main phase of the study implemented a series of classroom design experiments that produced knowledge on central aspects of PSTs' quantitative reasoning and the instructional experiences that support such reasoning. The second phase of the study implemented a series of design experiences that produced knowledge on central aspects of ISTs? reasoning that enable them to learn via interactions with their students. The third phase of the study incorporated project findings to investigate developmental shifts in middle school students? reasoning during their participation in small-group design experiments. By situating the project in classroom and instructional settings, Advancing Reasoning contributed research-based and practice-driven deliverables that improve the teaching and learning of mathematics.

 

Advancing Reasoning contributed important knowledge to the area of quantitative reasoning, which forms a CCSSM Standard for Mathematical Practice and a conceptual underpinning of secondary mathematics. More specifically, the project advanced research and practice oriented knowledge of differentiated approaches to supporting PSTs' quantitative reasoning. The generated products which include an extensive research base, as well as instructional materials ready for classroom implementation, fill a pressing need for concrete materials at the pre- and in-service levels that embody research-based knowledge in the area of quantitative reasoning. Advancing Reasoning also established a research-based secondary mathematics education course that transformed the preparation of approximately 140 pre- or in-service teachers during the project. The course will continue to transform the preparation of 20-40 PSTs per year after the project. As these PSTs carry their experiences into their classrooms, they will positively influence their future students and collaborating teachers. They will carry the course materials into their classroom as they incorporate them into their practice.

 

Beyond its classroom impact, the project generated knowledge and products have been disseminated to broader educational communities through an active social media presence, a project website, and scholarly publications and presentations geared toward research and practitioner communities. The project helps clarify the CCSSM Standards for Mathematical Practice, and the concrete examples of differentiated approaches to supporting PSTs' quantitative reasoning are of important use to mathematics educators at all levels. The accessible collection of research and educational products (see: https://sites.google.com/site/advancingreasoning/) provide a model program for transforming students? and teachers? quantitative reasoning that is adoptable at other institutions.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/24/2021
Modified by: Kevin C Moore
